moves.1. e4 Nf6: the Alekhine Defense: always a hard nut for White to crack...
moves.5... Nc6 6. h3: we give Black no time for Nb4: after Bxf3, Bxf3, Nb4, just c3...
moves.6... Bh5 7. g4 Bg6 8. c4: always a problem in the Alekhine: the Knight losing tempo...
moves.9... e6: Black needs space to castle: this also guards against d4-d5...
moves.10. Nc3: nonetheless, White enforces d5: we postpone castling until we know, what Black is up to...
moves.11... exd5 12. cxd5 Nb4 13. a3 Na6 14. b: a logical move: Black makes space for Nc7, after b4-b5...
moves.17. exd6 Bxd6 18. Bxd6 Qxc6: Black has sacrificed a piece: but that is not the end of it; Nc3, Nf3 and Bd6 are far from safe: after 0-0-0, Black has a mean edge...
moves.19. Qe2+: but White finds a hole in the Black defenses...
moves.20. Qe7+ Kc8 21. O-O: of course, Qxc3, Rc1 is losing...
moves.27. Nc3 Nxc5 28. Nxf7: but White comes out better in the trade: Nd6+ is a nasty threat...
moves.29. f4: making a bridge head for Nf7...
moves.29... Re3: trying to break up Whites' Kings' wing...
moves.31... Rxh3 32. Ne5: just in time to prevent Rf3+...
moves.35... Bb5: maybe not best: but after Rd2+, Re2, Black gets nowhere too...
moves.36. Rac1+ Kb6 37. Rcb1: de Bishop is pinned for now...
moves.38... Kc7: after Kc6, Rxe8, Black has no Bxe8...
moves.40. Nxb5+: taking out the last piece with check...
